citations.narrative:
There are three enclosures with drainage issues. The outdoor enclosure that contains 4 domestic cattle has a large
accumulation of mud and standing water around the grain feeding receptacle and water receptacle. The facility
representative states the cattle have additional food and water sources in their shelter. This enclosure’s drainage issue
has not been fixed from the last routine inspection. Two additional outdoor enclosures one containing 2 Highland cattle
and one containing 2 yaks have standing water and mud around their only food and water receptacles.
Poor drainage with areas of mud leads to animals being forced to walk and stand in wet conditions while eating or
drinking and may cause health problems. Cattle and similar species are more likely to have foot problems if kept in a wet
environment for an extended period of time. The outdoor enclosures must have adequate drainage so water may be
rapidly eliminated and provide the animals have a dry place to eat and drink.

There are two enclosures that have not been cleaned often enough to prevent accumulation of animal waste and have
contaminated the animals housed within. The outdoor enclosure housing one Asiatic water buffalo and a Brahman steer
has a large amount of wet excreta and straw several inches thick in front of the water and food receptacles. There is no
dry, clean space in the enclosure even the area under the roof and both animals are heavily soiled on all four legs,
abdomen and have clumps of mud and fecal material on their legs and tails. In another indoor enclosure housing 4 Zebu,
there is an approximately 2 weeks worth of fecal material surrounding their food and water receptacles. Enclosures not
cleaned as often as necessary to prevent accumulations of excreta create a disease hazard for the animals housed
within. The facility must remove excreta from primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent contamination of the
animals contained therein and to minimize disease hazards and to reduce odors.
To be corrected by: 20-March-2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
Paige Johnson, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOREnd Section

narrative:
3.127(c)  Repeat
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
There are three enclosures with drainage issues. The outdoor enclosure that contains 4 domestic cattle has a large 
accumulation of mud  and standing water around the grain feeding receptacle and water receptacle. The facility 
representative states the cattle have additional food and water sources in their shelter. This enclosure’s drainage issue 
has not been fixed from the last routine inspection. Two additional outdoor enclosures one containing 2 Highland cattle  
and one containing 2 yaks have standing water and mud around their only food and water receptacles.  
Poor drainage with areas of mud leads to animals being forced to walk and stand in wet conditions while eating or 
drinking and may cause health problems. Cattle and similar species are more likely to have foot problems if kept in a wet 
environment for an extended period of time. The outdoor enclosures must have adequate drainage so water may be 
rapidly eliminated and provide the animals have a dry place to eat and drink. 
3.131(a)  Direct
   
Sanitation. 
There are two enclosures that have not been cleaned often enough to prevent accumulation of animal waste and have 
contaminated the animals housed within. The outdoor enclosure housing one Asiatic water buffalo and a Brahman steer 
has a large amount of wet excreta and straw several inches thick in front of the water and food receptacles. There is no

dry, clean space in the enclosure even the area under the roof and both animals are heavily soiled on all four legs, 
abdomen and have clumps of mud and fecal material on their legs and tails. In another indoor enclosure housing 4 Zebu, 
there is an approximately 2 weeks worth of fecal material surrounding their food and water receptacles. Enclosures not 
cleaned as often as necessary to prevent accumulations of excreta create a disease hazard for the animals housed 
within. The facility must remove excreta from primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent contamination of the 
animals contained therein and to minimize disease hazards and to reduce odors.  
To be corrected by: 20-March-2023 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Paige Johnson, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOREnd Section

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
